tit.cmt: ローマ字表記を削除しました。

sen.j: 朱宮（緋宮）光子内親王（あけのみや てるこないしんのう、寛永11年7月1日 (旧暦)（1634年7月25日） - 享保12年10月6日 (旧暦)（1727年11月18日））は江戸時代初期の皇族。
sen.e: Akenomiya Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Akenomiya Teruko, July 25, 1634 - November 18, 1727) was a member of Imperial family in the early Edo period.
Akenomiya Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Akenomiya Teruko, July 25, 1634 - November 18, 1727) was a member of the Imperial Family in the early Edo period.
Imperial Princess Akenomiya Teruko (July 25, 1634 - November 18, 1727) was a member of the Imperial Family in the early Edo period.
sen.cmt: ローマ字表記を削除しました。

sen.j: 後水尾天皇の第八皇女。
sen.e: She was the eighth Princess of Emperor Gomizunoo.
She was the eighth Princess of Emperor Gomizunoo.
She was the eighth Princess of Emperor Gomizuno.

sen.j: 林丘寺開基。
sen.e: She founded Rinkyu-ji Temple.
She founded Rinkyu-ji Temple.
She founded Rinkyu-ji Temple.

sen.j: 号は照山元瑶。
sen.e: Her ingo (a title of respect given to a close female relative of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) was Shozan Genyo.
Her ingo (a title of respect given to a close female relative of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) was Shozan Genyo.
Her ingo (a title of respect given to a close female relative of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) was Shozan Genyo.

sen.j: 元瑶内親王、林丘寺宮と表記されることもある。
sen.e: She was also noted as Genyo Naishinno (Imperial Princess Genyo) or Rinkyu-ji no Miya.(Imperial Princess of Rinkyu-ji Temple.)
She was also noted as Genyo Naishinno (Imperial Princess Genyo) or Rinkyu-ji no Miya (Imperial Princess of Rinkyu-ji Temple).
She was also noted as Genyo Naishinno (Imperial Princess Genyo) or Rinkyu-ji no Miya (Imperial Princess of Rinkyu-ji Temple).

sen.j: 後に光子内親王となる朱宮は後水尾天皇と女官櫛笥隆子との皇女として生まれた。
sen.e: She was born as an Imperial Princess of Emperor Gomizunoo and his court lady Takako KUSHIGE, and was named Akenomiya who was later renamed Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Teruko.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: She was born as the Imperial Princess of Emperor Gomizunoo and his court lady Takako KUSHIGE; she was originally called Akenomiya but was later renamed Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Teruko).
Imperial Princess Teruko was born as the Imperial Princess of Emperor Gomizuno and his court lady Takako KUSHIGE; she was originally called Akenomiya but was later renamed Imperial Princess Teruko.
sen.cmt: 「Gomizuno」としローマ字表記を削除しました。

sen.j: そして、異母姉明正天皇の御世に育った。
sen.e: She was raised in the imperial reign of Emperor Meisho, her half sister.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: She was raised in the imperial reign of Emperor Meisho, her half-sister.
She was raised in the imperial reign of Emperor Meisho, her half-sister by the different mother.

sen.j: 後西天皇をはじめとした七人の同母兄弟がおり、異母兄弟は明正、後光明天皇、霊元天皇の三天皇を含む二十三人の大家族であった。
sen.e: She was a member of a large family composed of seven brothers-uterne including Emperor Gosai and twenty-three half-brothers including three Emperors, i.e. Emperor Meisho, Emperor Gokomyo and Emperor Reigen.
She was a member of a large family comprised of seven full brothers, including Emperor Gosai, and 23 half-brothers, including three emperors: Meisho, Gokomyo and Reigen.
She was a member of a large family comprised of seven uterine siblings, including Emperor Gosai, and 23 agnate siblings, including three emperors: Meisho, Gokomyo and Reigen.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 女官を生母として生まれた朱宮は本来であれば、他の多くの女官腹の皇女を同じく、内親王宣下を受けることもなく比丘尼御所で生涯を終えるのが通例であった。
sen.e: Since her real mother was a court lady, Akenomiya should have lived her life at an imperial palace for bikuni (female Buddhist disciples) without receiving proclamation of the title of Imperial Princess, in the same way as many other princesses born to court ladies.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Because her real mother was a court lady, Akenomiya should have lived her life at an imperial palace for bikuni (female Buddhist disciples) without receiving the proclamation of her title as Imperial Princess, in the same way as many other princesses born to court ladies.

Because her birth mother was a court lady, under normal circumstances, Akenomiya should have lived her life at an imperial palace for bikuni (female Buddhist disciples) like many other princesses born to court ladies without receiving the proclamation of the title as Imperial Princess.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 1638年（寛永15年）に父帝の中宮（当時は女院）徳川和子（東福門院）の養女となり、内親王宣下を受け光子内親王の忌み名を賜った。
sen.e: But, in 1638, Akenomiya was proclaimed Naishinno (Imperial Princess) with the given name of Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Teruko,) when she was adopted by Kazuko TOKUGAWA (Tofuku mon in,) who was then a close relative woman to Akenomiya's father, Emperor Gomizunoo and later became his consort.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in 1638 Akenomiya was proclaimed Naishinno (Imperial Princess) with the given name of Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Teruko), when she was adopted by Kazuko TOKUGAWA (Tofuku mon in), a woman who was closely related to Akenomiya's father, Emperor Gomizunoo, and later became his consort.

However, in 1638, Akenomiya was adopted by Kazuko TOKUGAWA (Tofukumonin), Chugu (the second consort of an emperor) (at that time Nyoin (a close female relative of the Emperor of comparable standing)) of her father and was proclaimed Imperial Princess with the given name of Imperial Princess Teruko.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 時期は不明であるが、養母東福門院の薦めにより、四代将軍徳川家綱との縁談が持ち上がったこともあるという。
sen.e: Though the time is not clearly known, it was told that Akenomiya had an offer of marrying Ietsuna TOKUGAWA, the fourth Tokugawa Shogun, on recommendation of her adoptive mother Tofukumonin.
Though the precise date is not known, it was said that Akenomiya had an offer of marriage to Ietsuna TOKUGAWA, the fourth Tokugawa shogun, on the recommendation of her adoptive mother, Tofukumonin.
Though the precise date is not known, it was said that Akenomiya had an offer of marriage to Ietsuna TOKUGAWA, the fourth Tokugawa shogun, on the recommendation of her adoptive mother, Tofukumonin.

sen.j: しかしながら、公家と武家との通婚や養子縁組を良しとしなかった父帝後水尾天皇の反対によりこの縁談は成立することはなかった。
sen.e: However, this marrage was not realized because her father, Emperor Gomizunoo, opposed to it, frowning on any marrage or adoption between kuge (court nobles) and buke (samurai families.)
This marriage was not realized because her father, Emperor Gomizunoo, was opposed to it, since he frowned on any marriage or adoption between kuge (court nobles) and buke (samurai families).
This marriage was not realized because her father, Emperor Gomizuno, was opposed to it, since he frowned on any marriage or adoption between kuge (court nobles) and buke (samurai families).

sen.j: その後、内親王に縁談はなく生涯を独身で過ごした。
sen.e: Since then, the Imperial Princess had no marrage offer and remained single all her life.
The Imperial Princess had no subsequent marriage offer, so she remained single throughout her life.
The Imperial Princess had no subsequent marriage offer, so she remained single throughout her life.

sen.j: 後水尾天皇は多くの女官たちとの間に多数の皇子女をなしたが、東福門院と女官所生の皇子女とは仲が良く、また、母が異なる皇子女同士も非常に良好な関係であった。
sen.e: While many princes and princesses were born between Emperor Gomizunoo and his court ladies, Empress Tofukumonin got along with them well, and each of them born from different mothers were also in good relationship.

Many princes and princesses were born between Emperor Gomizunoo and his court ladies, Empress Tofukumonin got along with them well, and the relationships among them were good despite their birth from different mothers.
Many princes and princesses were born between Emperor Gomizuno and his court ladies, but Tofukumonin got along with them well, and the relationships among those born from different mothers were good.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 後水尾院と東福門院をはじめ兄弟たち、院の兄弟、旧知の公家、女官などとたびたび集まり親交を深めたという。
sen.e: Gomizuoin, Tofukumonin, their children, their brothers and sisters, their well-acquainted court nobles, court ladies and others gathered together frequently to deepen their good relationship.
Gomizuoin, Tofukumonin, their children, their brothers and sisters, their well-acquainted court nobles, court ladies and others gathered together frequently to deepen their relationships.

Including Gomizuoin and Tofukumonin, their children, their brothers and sisters, their well-acquainted court nobles, court ladies and others gathered together frequently to deepen their relationships.

sen.j: 内親王もこれによく参加し遊びや文芸などを楽しんだ。
sen.e: Also, Akenomiya Naishinno (Imperial Princess Akenomiya) joined such gatherings and enjoyed various plays, arts and literatures.
Akenomiya Naishinno (Imperial Princess Akenomiya) also joined such gatherings to enjoy arts, literature and various plays.
Imperial Princess Akenomiya also joined such gatherings to enjoy arts, literature and various plays.
sen.cmt: ローマ字読みを削除しました。

sen.j: 多くの兄弟姉妹中で幼い頃から聡明であった内親王は異母妹である常子内親王とともに父帝より特別に寵愛されたという。
sen.e: Among her many brothers and sisters, Akenomiya was so bright and intellectual from her childhood that her father Emperor specially favored her together with her half sister Tsuneko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Tsuneko.)

Among her many brothers and sisters, Akenomiya had been so bright and intellectual since childhood that her father, the Emperor, particularly favored her, as well as her half-sister, Tsuneko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Tsuneko).

Among her many brothers and sisters, Akenomiya had been so bright and intellectual since childhood that her father, the Emperor, particularly favored her, as well as her half-sister by different mother, Imperial Princess Tsuneko.
sen.cmt: ローマ字読みを削除しました。

sen.j: なお、仙台藩三代藩主伊達綱宗は母方のいとこである。
sen.e: In addition, Thunamune DATE, the third lord of Sendai Domain, was her cousin on her mothers side.
Additionally, Thunamune DATE, the third lord of the Sendai domain, was her cousin on her mother's side.
Additionally, Tsunamune DATE, the third lord of the Sendai domain, was her cousin on her mother's side.

sen.j: 父帝後水尾天皇が黄檗宗の庇護に努めたこともあり、内親王も幼少の頃より、高僧の法話に聞き入り仏教への親和を深めていった。
sen.e: Since her father, Emperor Gomizunoo, endeavored to give sanctuary to Obaku-shu (Obaku Sect,) the Imperial Princess could deepen her sense of belongings to the Buddhism through listening to preaches of high priests from her childhood.

Since her father, Emperor Gomizunoo, had endeavored to give sanctuary to Obaku-shu (the Obaku sect), since her childhood the Imperial Princess experienced a deepened sense of belonging to Buddhism as she listened to the preaching of high priests.

Since her father, Emperor Gomizuno, had endeavored to give sanctuary to the Obaku sect, since her childhood the Imperial Princess experienced a deepened sense of belonging to Buddhism as she listened to the preaching of high priests.
sen.cmt: 「Gomizuno」とし、ローマ字読みを削除しました。

sen.j: 1665年（寛文5年）には黄檗宗の龍渓性潜により菩薩式を受け、道号照山、法諱元瑶の号を受ける。
sen.e: In 1665, she received Bosatsu-shiki (literally, ceremony of Bodhisattva) from Ryokeishosen of Obaku Sect, and dogo (pseudonym as a priest) of Shozan and hoi (given name to a Buddhist priest) of Genyo.
sen.cmt: 「菩薩式」の意味不明で。とりあえず、逐語訳としてceremony of Bodhisattvaとしておきました。
sen.e: In 1665, she received Bosatsu-shiki (literally, ceremony of Bodhisattva) from Ryokeishosen of the Obaku sect, and the dogo (pseudonym as a priest) of Shozan and hoi (given name to a Buddhist priest) of Genyo.

In 1665, she received Bosatsu-shiki (literally, ceremony of Bodhisattva) from Ryukei Shosen of the Obaku sect, and the dogo (pseudonym as a priest) of Shozan and hoi (given name to a Buddhist priest) of Genyo.
sen.cmt: 英語書籍にRyukei Shosenとありましたので、名前の順序はこれに従いました。[http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=hfMkpD_Xr3sC&pg=PA301&lpg=PA301&dq=Ryukei+SHosen&source=bl&ots=Z6sqCKFgE6&sig=hKo47U77d-ndmZCyOJtpv3zLCKk&hl=ja&ei=njnUSoyNMZKgkQX9uozvDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CAsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Ryukei%20SHosen&f=false]

sen.j: 1680年（延宝8年）には父・後水尾法皇が死去し、遺言により内親王は知行三百石が与えられた。
sen.e: In 1680, when her father, Emperor Gomizunoo passed away, she was enfeoffed three hundred koku by Emperor's will.
In 1680, upon the passing of her father, Emperor Gomizunoo, she was bequeathed 300 koku according to his will.
In 1680, upon the passing of her father, Emperor Gomizuno, she was bequeathed 300 koku (approximately 83.4 cubic meters) according to his will.
sen.cmt: 「Gomizuno」とし、ローマ字読みを削除、「三百石」を補足しました。

sen.j: その二ヵ月後に大覚寺に入寺し、天龍寺の僧天外のもとで剃髪し、嵯峨一灯庵に幽棲した。
sen.e: In two months after that, she entered Daikaku-ji Temple as a priest to be tonsured byTengai, a monk of Tenryu-ji Temple, and sequestered herself from the world to live in a hermitage in Saga named Itto-an (literally, a hermitage of one lamp.)

Two months later, she entered Daikaku-ji Temple as a priest to be tonsured by Tengai, a monk of the temple, and sequestered herself from the world to live in a hermitage in Saga called Itto-an (literally, a hermitage of one lamp).

Two months later, she entered Daikaku-ji Temple as a priest to be tonsured by Tengai, a monk of Tenryu-ji temple, and sequestered herself from the world to live in a hermitage in Saga called Itto-an (literally, a hermitage of one lamp).

sen.j: 二年後の1682年（天和 (日本)2年）には修学院村に林丘寺を建立し、開基となった。
sen.e: Two years later, she founded Rinkyu-ji Temple in Shugakuin Village in 1682.
Two years later, in 1682, she founded Rinkyu-ji Temple in Shugakuin Village.
Two years later, in 1682, she built Rinkyu-ji Temple in Shugakuin Village and became the founder.

sen.j: 父帝の生前、内親王は修学院離宮内に別殿を賜って楽只軒と称した。
sen.e: When her father, Emperor Gomizunoo, was alive, she was presented a separate palace, named Rakushiken, within the premises of Shugakuin Rikyu (Shugakuin Imperial Villa.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When her father, Emperor Gomizunoo, was alive, she was given a separate palace, called Rakushiken, within the premises of Shugakuin Rikyu (Shugakuin Imperial Villa).
When her father, Emperor Gomizuno, was alive, she was given a separate palace, called Rakushiken, within the premises of Shugakuin Rikyu (Shugakuin Imperial Villa).

sen.j: この朱宮御所（音羽御所）を寺に改め林丘寺とした。
sen.e: This palace was so called Akenomiya Gosho or Otowa Gosho (Palace of Akenomiya or Otowa), which was later rebuilt into a temple and called Rinkyu-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This palace was so called Akenomiya Gosho or Otowa Gosho (Palace of Akenomiya or Otowa), which was later rebuilt into a temple and called Rinkyu-ji Temple.
This palace was so called Akenomiya Gosho or Otowa Gosho (Palace of Akenomiya or Otowa), which was later rebuilt into a temple and called Rinkyu-ji Temple.

sen.j: 客殿は養母東福門院の旧御所を移築したものである。
sen.e: Its reception hall was originally the old palace of her adoptive mother Tofukumonin which was moved to the present place.
Its reception hall was originally the old palace of her adoptive mother Tofukumonin, which had been moved to its present place.
Its reception hall was originally the old palace of her adoptive mother Tofukumonin, which had been moved to its present place.

sen.j: 生母櫛笥隆子の亡き後、光子内親王は寺を出ることはなく、経典の読謡や写経をして過ごした。
sen.e: After her real mother Takako KUSHIGE died, Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Teruko) stayed forever in the temple reading aloud and copying sutras.
Subsequent to the death of her real mother, Takako KUSHIGE, Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Teruko) remained in the temple, where she read aloud and copied sutras.
Subsequent to the death of her real mother, Takako KUSHIGE, Imperial Princess Teruko remained in the temple, where she read aloud and copied sutras.
sen.cmt: ローマ字読みを削除しました。

sen.j: また、捨て子を引き取り養育したという。
sen.e: Also, she is said to have nurtured abondoned children.
Also, she is said to have nurtured abondoned children.
Also, she is said to have nurtured abondoned children.

sen.j: 1707年（宝永4年）に異母弟霊元天皇の皇女亀宮（後の元秀女王）が林丘寺に入ると普門院と号し隠居した。
sen.e: In 1707, Kamenomiya (later Princess Genshu,) who was a princess of Emperor Reigen, Akinomiya's half brother, entered Rinkyu-ji Temple as a priest, when Akinomiya retired and called herself Fumonin.
In 1707, Kamenomiya (later Princess Genshu), who was a princess of Emperor Reigen, Akinomiya's half-brother, entered Rinkyu-ji Temple as a priest, when Akinomiya retired and called herself Fumonin.

In 1707, Kamenomiya (later Princess Genshu), who was a daughter of Emperor Reigen, Akinomiya's half-brother from a different mother, entered Rinkyu-ji Temple as a priest when Akinomiya retired and called herself Fumonin.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 光子内親王は1727年（享保12年）に94歳の高齢で亡くなった。
sen.e: In 1727, Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Teruko) died in her age of ninety-four.
In 1727, Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Teruko) died; she was 94 years of age.
In 1727, Imperial Princess Teruko died at an advanced age of 94.
sen.cmt: ローマ字読みを削除し表現を少し変えました。

sen.j: 時の天皇は中御門天皇であり、内親王は六代の天皇の御世を生きたこととなる。
sen.e: Then the current emperor was Emperor Nakamikado, which means she had lived reigns of total six emperors.
It was the reign of Emperor Nakamikado, the sixth to reign during her lifetime.
It was the reign of Emperor Nakamikado, the sixth Emperor during her lifetime.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 当代一級の文化人であった後水尾天皇を父に、芸術と文化のパトロンであった東福門院を養母に持ち寛永文化が花開いた時代に育った内親王もまた、和歌や書、絵画に優れた才能を残した人であった。
sen.e: With her father, Emperor Gomizunoo, who was the first class cultural figure of the day, and her adopted mother, Tofukumonin, who was a patron of contemporary arts and cultures, Akenomiya Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Teruko Akenomiya) was raised in the flowering age of Kanei periof culture and became one of the greatest talents of Japanese poetries, calligraphies and paintings.

With her father Emperor Gomizunoo, who was the premier cultural figure of the day, and her adopted mother Tofukumonin, who was a patron of contemporary arts and culture, Akenomiya Teruko Naishinno (Imperial Princess Teruko Akenomiya) was raised in the flowering age of Kanei period culture and became one of the greatest talents of Japanese poetry, calligraphy and painting.

With her father Emperor Gomizuno, who was the premier cultural figure of the day, and her adopted mother Tofukumonin, who was a patron of contemporary arts and culture, Imperial Princess Teruko was raised in the age of flourished culture of Kanei period and became one of the greatest talents of Japanese poetry, calligraphy and painting.
sen.cmt: 「Gomizuno」とし「寛永文化が花開いた時代」の表現を変更しました。

sen.j: 特に、絵画は狩野安信と狩野派を学んだ黄檗宗の卓峯道香に手ほどきを受け、多数の作品を残した。
sen.e: Especially, she left a lot of painting works after having learned the basics of painting from Yasunobu KANO and Doko TAKUO, a priest of Obaku Sect who had mastered paintings of Kano school.
sen.cmt: 「卓峯道香」の読み方不明です。 「狩野安信」と「卓峯道香」が同格と解釈して訳しました。
sen.e: Particularly, she left a great number of paintings, having learned the basics of painting from Yasunobu KANO and Doko TAKUO, a priest of the Obaku sect who had mastered the painting style of the Kano school.

Particularly, she left a great number of paintings, having learned the basics of painting from Yasunobu KANO and Doko TAKUO (卓峯道香), a priest of the Obaku sect who mastered the painting style of the Kano school.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 自画像と父後水尾天皇の肖像画二点、花鳥図などが残されているが、残された作品の多くは修行の一環としての観音像を描いたものである。
sen.e: The works she left include two portraits of herself and her father Empero Gomizunoo, and kacho-zu (paintings of flowers and birds,) while many of them are portraits of Kannon (Deity of Mercy) which she painted in her course of disciplining.

She left two portraits of herself and her father Emperor Gomizunoo, as well as kacho-zu (paintings of flowers and birds), but many others are portraits of Kannon (Deity of Mercy), which she painted in her course of discipline.

She left two portraits of herself and her father Emperor Gomizuno, as well as kacho-zu (paintings of flowers and birds), but many others are portraits of Kannon (Deity of Mercy), which she painted in her course of discipline.

sen.j: 千点以上の観音像を描き、三千点という樒葉（しきみば）観音像を創り、檀家や寺社がこれを求めたという。
sen.e: She is told to have painted more than one thousand of Kannon figures and made more than three thousand Shikimiba Kannon, which were all solicited by parishioners and other temples.
She is said to have painted more than 1,000 Kannon figures and more than 3,000 Shikimiba Kannon, which had all been solicited by parishioners and other temples.

She is said to have painted more than 1,000 Kannon figures and more than 3,000 Shikimiba Kannon (images of Kannon made of powdered leaves of Japanese star anise), which had all been solicited by parishioners and other temples.
sen.cmt: 「樒葉観音像」の英訳を補足しました。

sen.j: ｢讃観音大士伽陀集｣二巻の撰述がある。
sen.e: Also left are compilations of two scrolls of "San Kannon Daishi Gada Shu."
sen.cmt: ｢讃観音大士伽陀集｣の対訳不明です。
sen.e: Also left are compilations of two scrolls of "San Kannon Daishi Gada Shu."
She also compiled two volumes of "San Kannon Daishi kada shu" (a compilation of poems regarding Kannon (Deity of Mercy) sponsored by the Imperial Princess Teruko).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。
